elements.content: Proton exchange reaction of isolated or in situ prepared heterobimetallic peralkylated Sm complexes with sterically demanding mono- and bisphenols led to the formation of aluminum alkyl samarium-aryloxide adducts in good yields. Divalent complexes formulated as Sm[(μ-2,6-bis(phenylphenoxy))]2[(μ-Me)(AlMe2)]2 (1), (Sm{μ-η6′ -[6,6′-methylene-bis(2-tert-butyl-4-methylphenoxy)][AlMe2]}{μ-Me}2{AlMe})(μ-Me) (3), {Sm-μ-[6,6′-methylenebis(2-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol)][μ-Me2AlMe2]}2 (6), and Sm-{μ-[6,6′-methylenebis(2-tert-butyl-4-methylphenoxy)]}2-μ-AlMe2 (7) were isolated and characterized including via solid structure determination. The reactivity of these compounds toward both oxidation and insertion into the [Sm−Me−Al] fragment was probed with both CO2 and tert-butylisocyanate, affording Sm{[(μ-2,6-bis(phenylphenoxy))2AlMe2]-[μ-(acetato)-(2,6-bis(phenylphenoxy))AlMe2][1,2-dimethoxyethane]}{C6H14}0.25 (2) and Sm{μ-[6,6′-methylenebis(2-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol)]-μ-[N-tert-butylacetamidate]AlMe}2{C7H8}1.5 (4), respectively. The trivalent 6 exhibited significant activity as a catalyst for ethylene polymerization without the need for further activation and which may be regarded as an example of a single-component lanthanide ethylene polymerization catalyst without a cyclopentadienyl ligand.

elements.content:
Single-component catalytic activity for ethylene polymerization was obtained for a samarium aryloxide/aluminate complex only if the trivalent state was preserved and π-bonding interaction avoided

Introduction

Lowvalent samarium displays one of the most remarkable and unpredictable chemical reactivities, which is characterized by a large variety of transformations with the most diversified substrates. In fact, the appearance of the first of these remarkable findings in the literature almost 25 years ago has marked the beginning of modern fblock organometallic chemistry. Perhaps the key to understand such a remarkable and unique chemical behavior is not only the strong reducing power of divalent samarium in performing oneelectron attacks but also the ability to stabilize (at least for a sufficiently long time) the corresponding radical type of intermediates. In subsequent steps, a variety of radicallike couplings generate the final products. Indeed, the cooperative attack of more than one divalent center on the substrate is a trend in this chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Single-component catalytic activity for ethylene polymerization was obtained for a samarium aryloxide/aluminate complex only if the trivalent state was preserved and π-bonding interaction avoided

Introduction

Lowvalent samarium displays one of the most remarkable and unpredictable chemical reactivities, which is characterized by a large variety of transformations with the most diversified substrates. In fact, the appearance of the first of these remarkable findings in the literature almost 25 years ago has marked the beginning of modern fblock organometallic chemistry. Perhaps the key to understand such a remarkable and unique chemical behavior is not only the strong reducing power of divalent samarium in performing oneelectron attacks but also the ability to stabilize (at least for a sufficiently long time) the corresponding radical type of intermediates. In subsequent steps, a variety of radicallike couplings generate the final products. Indeed, the cooperative attack of more than one divalent center on the substrate is a trend in this chemistry.

elements.content: Given the versatility to promote C−C bond forming reactions, including a rare and desirable case of CO2 reductive coupling, the possibility of using divalent Sm for polymerizing olefins has not escaped the attention of researchers in the field. Samarocene has provided one of the very first singlecomponent ethylene polymerization catalysts, producing a polymer with molecular weight so high that it could not be measured. Even in this case, the polymerization initiation step may be envisioned as following the usual trend of cooperative attack of two metal centers at the two ends of the ethylene molecule. The thermal robustness of the Sm−C bond is most likely responsible at this stage for the endless chain growth and the uniqueness of the polymer generated.

elements.content: As usual, the particular nature of the ligand system is central to the performances of divalent samarium. Using a large variety of ligands, other than Cplike derivatives, has so far produced only remarkable structures, but none were able to generate even a fraction of the complex transformations performed by the samarocenes. Only in the case of πbonded polypyrrolide anions, somewhat related to the Cp rings, has the reducing power apparently surpassed the samarocenes. This was at least in the case of dinitrogen activation. The reactivity with ethylene seems instead to have taken a step back with these particular complexes in the sense that no singlecomponent catalytic activity has been observed but only sideon ethylene coordination. On the other hand, we have observed that by using πbonded ligand systems containing heteroatoms, Lewis acidic alkali cations are very often retained, thereby significantly affecting the redox potential of the divalent Sm center. Thus, it seems possible that even ethylene activation (e.g., from labile coordination, to reduction and polymerization) could be finetuned through the appropriate selection of the ancillary Lewis acids retained as part of the anionic metalate structures of divalent samarium.

elements.content: In an attempt to clarify this behavior, we have carried out the present study in the chemistry of lowvalent samarium by using aryloxides as ancillary ligands and alkyl aluminum as Lewis acids. The selection of bulky aryloxides was suggested by the strong affinity for Al of the oxygen donor atom, thereby enhancing the possibility for aggregation. We wished to verify the possibility that the strong coordination to an acidic AlR3 residue could favor the πbonding mode of the aryloxide aromatic ring. We were also interested in assessing the ability of divalent samarium to perform pure insertion reactions rather than reductions. In other words we wish to understand whether a divalent SmR function could grow polyethylene chains via repetitive insertion into the Sm(II)−C bond.

In other words we wish to understand whether a divalent SmR function could grow polyethylene chains via repetitive insertion into the Sm(II)-C bond.

elements.content: While this work was in progress, Anwander has reported a series of heterometallic Ln/alane complexes determining two prevalent features in these complexes: adduct formation and ligand rearrangement. Herein we report our independent observations.

elements.content: All manipulations were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with rigorous exclusion of oxygen and water using standard Schlenk and glovebox techniques. Hexane, toluene, and THF solvents were purified by passing through Al2O3filled columns and deoxygenated prior to use by several vacuum/nitrogen purges. DME was dried for 12 h over LiAlH4 and distilled under N2 prior to utilization. Benzened 6, toluened 8, and THFd 8 were obtained from C/D/N Isotopes, dried over freshly activated molecular sieves (4 Å) for 10 days, and distilled under an N2 atmosphere. Trimethylaluminum solution in hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used as received. 2,6Diphenylphenol and 2,2′methylenebis(6tertbutyl4methylphenol) were purchased from Aldrich, dried under vacuum at room temperature for 48 h, and then used without further purification. Complexes [Sm(AlMe4)2] n and Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 were synthesized according to literature procedures. NMR spectra were recorded at 293 K on a Varian Inova 500 MHz spectrometer. Chemical shifts were referenced to internal solvent resonances and are reported in parts per million relative to Me4Si. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN analyzer. Data for Xray singlecrystal structure determination were collected with a Bruker diffractometer equipped with a 1K SMART CCD area detector.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Part

All manipulations were performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with rigorous exclusion of oxygen and water using standard Schlenk and glovebox techniques. Hexane, toluene, and THF solvents were purified by passing through Al2O3filled columns and deoxygenated prior to use by several vacuum/nitrogen purges. DME was dried for 12 h over LiAlH4 and distilled under N2 prior to utilization. Benzened 6, toluened 8, and THFd 8 were obtained from C/D/N Isotopes, dried over freshly activated molecular sieves (4 Å) for 10 days, and distilled under an N2 atmosphere. Trimethylaluminum solution in hexane was purchased from Aldrich and used as received. 2,6Diphenylphenol and 2,2'methylenebis(6tertbutyl4methylphenol) were purchased from Aldrich, dried under vacuum at room temperature for 48 h, and then used without further purification. Complexes [Sm(AlMe4)2] n   and Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3  were synthesized according to literature procedures. NMR spectra were recorded at 293 K on a Varian Inova 500 MHz spectrometer. Chemical shifts were referenced to internal solvent resonances and are reported in parts per million relative to Me4Si. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 CHN analyzer. Data for Xray singlecrystal structure determination were collected with a Bruker diffractometer equipped with a 1K SMART CCD area detector.

elements.content: Catalytic performance of the complexes was tested in a 200 mL highpressure Buchi reactor containing a heating/cooling jacket. A preweighed amount of catalyst was dissolved in 10 mL of toluene under N2 and injected into the preheated reactor already charged with toluene and cocatalyst, if necessary (total volume 100 mL). Solutions were heated with a thermostatic bath and pressurized with ethylene, maintaining the desired pressure throughout the run. Polymerizations were quenched by addition of EtOH and HCl. The resulting polymer was isolated by filtration, sonicated with an acidified ethanol solution, rinsed, and thoroughly dried prior to mass determination. Molecular weight and molecularweight distributions of the polymers were determined by means of gel permeation chromatography on a PLGPC210 equipped with refractiveindex and viscosity detectors and a 3 H PLgel 10 mm MIXEDB column set at 135 °C with 1,2,4trichlorobenzene as solvent. The molecular weight of PE was referenced to a polystyrene (M w = 65 500, PDI = 1.02) standard sample.

elements.content: A solution of 2,6diphenylphenol (0.407 g, 1.65 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was slowly added to a suspension of Sm(AlMe4)2 (0.268 g, 0.83 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction was accompanied by a fast color change from pale yellow to deep brownred and vigorous gas evolution. After 4 h of stirring at room temperature, the volume of the reaction mixture was reduced to 4 mL in vacuo and the mother liquor was allowed to stand at room temperature for crystallization. After 48 h dark red prisms of 1 separated and were washed with cold (−35 °C) toluene (3 mL) and dried in vacuo (0.565 g, 0.72 mmol 87%). Anal. for C42H44Al2O2Sm found (calcd): C 64.11 (64.25), H 5.53 (5.65).

Preparation of Sm[(μ2,6bis(phenylphenol))]2[(μMe)(AlMe2)]2 (1)

Method A

A solution of 2,6diphenylphenol (0.407 g, 1.65 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was slowly added to a suspension of Sm(AlMe4)2 (0.268 g, 0.83 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction was accompanied by a fast color change from pale yellow to deep brownred and vigorous gas evolution. After 4 h of stirring at room temperature, the volume of the reaction mixture was reduced to 4 mL in vacuo and the mother liquor was allowed to stand at room temperature for crystallization. After 48 h dark red prisms of 1 separated and were washed with cold (-35 °C) toluene (3 mL) and dried in vacuo (0.565 g, 0.72 mmol 87%). Anal. for C42H44Al2O2Sm found (calcd): C 64.11 (64.25), H 5.53 (5.65).

elements.content: A solution of Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 (0.200 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was treated with solution of AlMe3 in toluene (0.97 mL, 1.94 mmol, 2.0 M). A slight color change occurred. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for an additional 30 min. After that period a solution of 2,6diphenylphenol (0.108 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added dropwise to the reaction mixture. The immediate color darkening was accompanied by a vigorous gas evolution. The solution was brought to the boiling point and evaporated to a volume of about 3 mL. The reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature. After 12 h, dark red prisms of 1 separated (0.203 g, 0.26 mmol, 81%). Analytical data and crystallographic cell parameters were nearly identical to those of the material isolated by method A.

elements.content: A dark redbrown solution of 1 (0.450 g, 0.57 mmol) in toluene (7 mL) was exposed to CO2 (1 atm). No color change was observed at room temperature, and the reaction mixture was brought to the boiling point and refluxed under CO2 atmosphere for 15 min. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the toluene solvent was removed in vacuo. The resulting dark red oil was redissolved in the minimum amount of DME (4 mL) under an N2 atmosphere. The DME solution was layered with hexanes (13 mL). After 48 h, dark red prisms of 2 were formed from the solution (0.283 g, 0.24 mmol, 42%). Upon drying in vacuo crystals rapidly deteriorated with formation of a red powdery material. Anal. for a dried sample of C64H64Al2O7Sm found (calcd): C 66.74 (66.87), H 5.57 (5.61). 1H NMR (500 MHz, benzened 6, 20 °C): δ 7.75(3H, ortho, paraAr′H), 7.74(3H, ortho, paraAr′H), 7.50(10H, Ar′′H), 7.45(2H, paraArH), 7.36(1H, paraArH), 7.15(2H, metaArH), 7.04(2H, metaAr′H), 6.96(4H, metaArH), 6.90(2H, metaAr′H), 6.42(6H, ortho,paraAr′H), 6.18(4H, metaAr′H), 3.48(broad, 3H, CH 3COO), 2.08(3H, AlCH 3), 2.05(3H, AlCH 3), −0.22(6H, AlCH 3).

Vigorous gas evolution and significant color change from pale pink to deep red were observed upon mixing. elements.content: A solution of tertbutylisocyanate (0.045 g, 0.46 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added dropwise with vigorous stirring to a solution of 3 (0.275 g, 0.43 mmol) in the same solvent (10 mL). No significant immediate color change was observed from the initial deep red, and stirring was continued for an additional 5 h. After that period of time, the volume was reduced in vacuo to about 4 mL. The solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for 3 days, after which large greenishbrown prisms of 4 separated. The crystalline mass was isolated, washed with cold toluene (−35 °C), and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.235 g, 0.18 mmol, 43%.). Anal. for C70.5H102N2Al2O6Sm found (calcd): C 66.21 (66.26), H 7.98 (8.05), N 2.15 (2.19).

elements.content: For all the compounds, the results presented are the best of three data collection trials. The crystals were mounted on thin glass fibers using paraffin oil and cooled to the data collection temperature. Data were collected on a BrukerAXS SMART 1k CCD diffractometer. Data for the compounds 1, 2, 3, and 7 were collected with a sequence of 0.3° ω scans at 0°, 120°, and 240° in φ. To obtain acceptable redundancy data for compounds 4, 5, and 6, the sequence of 0.3° ω scans at 0°, 90°, 180°, and 270° in φ was used. Initial unit cell parameters were determined from 60 data frames collected at different sections of the Ewald sphere. Semiempirical absorption corrections based on equivalent reflections were applied. Systematic absences in the diffraction data set and unitcell parameters were consistent with monoclinic P21/n for 1 and 2, monoclinic P21/c for 3 and 7, and triclinic P1̅ for 4, 5, and 6. Solutions in centrosymmetric space groups for all of the compounds yielded chemically reasonable and computationally stable results of refinement. The structures were solved by direct methods, completed with difference Fourier synthesis, and refined with fullmatrix leastsquares procedures based on F 2. In all structures compound molecules were located in general positions. The structure of complex 3 represents a polymeric chain with monomers connected through −CH3 group coordination to the Sm metal center of the next monomeric unit. In this structure each monomeric unit is symmetry related to the next one through a 21 axis symmetry operator. Complex 6 demonstrates a dimeric arrangement where two monomeric units are related by an inversion center symmetry operator. Carbon atoms of a cocrystallized hexane solvent molecule in 2 as well as carbon atoms of cocrystallized toluene solvent molecules in 4 were refined isotropicaly due to partial occupancy coupled with significant thermal motion disorder and in order to maintain an optimal datatoparameter ratio. In all the structures, all nonhydrogen atoms, with the exceptions mentioned above, were refined with anisotropic displacement coefficients. All hydrogen atoms were treated as idealized contributions. All scattering factors are contained in several versions of the SHELXTL program library version 6.12. Crystallographic data for all structures are reported in the .

elements.content: Following the strategy ingeniously designed by Evans and Anwander, we have used the divalent Sm[AlMe4]2 and the in situ generated trivalent Sm[AlMe4]3 (obtained by reacting Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 with 6 equiv of Me3Al in toluene) as starting materials to be reacted with 2,6Ph2C6H3OH. The reaction in toluene was accompanied by vigorous gas evolution and significant color change. After suitable workup, the divalent Sm[(μ2,6bis(phenylphenol))]2[(μMe)(AlMe2)]2 (1) was obtained in high yield and crystalline form from either reaction, regardless of the different metal oxidation state of the starting material (Scheme ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Following the strategy ingeniously designed by Evans and Anwander, we have used the divalent Sm[AlMe4]2 and the in situ generated trivalent Sm[AlMe4]3 (obtained by reacting Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 with 6 equiv of Me3Al in toluene) as starting materials to be reacted with 2,6Ph2C6H3OH. The reaction in toluene was accompanied by vigorous gas evolution and significant color change. After suitable workup, the divalent Sm[(μ2,6bis(phenylphenol))]2[(μMe)(AlMe2)]2 (1) was obtained in high yield and crystalline form from either reaction, regardless of the different metal oxidation state of the starting material (Scheme ).

<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="om-2009-00172n_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The crystal structure of 1 comprises a divalent Sm center in a distorted pseudooctahedral environment (Figure ). One axial and one equatorial position of the octahedron are occupied by two oxygen atoms of the two aryloxide ligands [Sm(1)−O(1) = 2.496(2) Å, Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.534(2) Å, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 115.04(7)°]. Two other equatorial positions are occupied by two methyl groups [Sm(1)−C(21) = 2.811(3) Å, Sm(1)−C(42) = 2.827(3) Å, C(21)−Sm(1)−C(42) = 100.19(10)°] in a cisoidtype arrangement [O(1)−Sm(1)−C(21) = 67.96(8)°, O(2)−Sm(1)−C(42) = 67.73(8)°]. Two η6coordinated orthophenyl groups [Sm(1)−centroid(1) = 2.956(3) Å, Sm(1)−centroid(2) = 2.954(3) Å, centroid(1)−Sm(1)−centroid(1) = 110.02(8)°] are situated on the second axial and equatorial positions, defining a “bent sandwich” type of structure.

elements.content: Anwander has previously proposed that complex 1 may be prepared via abstraction of THF by a strong Lewis acid on the appropriate Sm complex. The utilization of Smaluminate as a starting material reported here resulted in a transformation facilitating crystallization. Complex 1 is thermally robust and, in spite of the presence of Sm−C bonds and the expected labile sandwich structure, does not display singlecomponent catalytic activity with ethylene even under harsh reaction conditions. The use of a variety of alkyl aluminum reagents as possible activators did not modify the outcome. This inertness was not anticipated, and to further probe the reactivity of the Sm−C bond in this divalent organosamarium complex, we have carried out the reaction of 1 with CO2 (1) to assess the ability of the Sm−C bond to insert CO2 and (2) to probe the reducing power of the divalent center toward possible CO2 reductive coupling. Upon exposure of a toluene solution of 1 to carbon dioxide, only a slight color change was observed. Roomtemperature reactions required several hours for completion. Unfortunately, all crystallization attempts from noncoordinating solvents failed to yield suitable crystalline material. Only upon layering a DME solution with hexanes was it possible to obtain complex 2 in crystalline form (Scheme , Figure ).

elements.content: In complex 2 the Sm(II) atom is placed in the center of a distorted pentagonalbipyramidal environment with the equatorial plane defined by two oxygen atoms of a coordinated DME molecule [Sm(1)−O(6) = 2.667(6) Å, Sm(1)−O(7) = 2.623(6) Å] and two oxygen atoms from two different aryloxide ligands [Sm(1)−O(1) = 2.558(6) Å, Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.603(6) Å, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 60.02(17)°, O(2)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 85.4(2)°]. Two aryloxide ligands are in turn bridging the same AlMe2 unit [Al(1)−O(1) = 1.832(7) Å, Al(1)−O(2) = 1.831(6) Å, O(1)−Al(1)−O(2) = 89.6(3)°] (Figure ). The fifth equatorial position around Sm is occupied by the oxygen atom of one acetate anion [Sm(1)−O(3) = 2.405(7) Å, O(3)−Sm(1)−O(7) = 78.5(2)°, O(3)−Sm(1)−O(1) = 75.0(2)°], which in turn bridges an ArOAlMe2 unit [Al(2)−O(4) = 1.827(8) Å]. The two axial positions of the pentagonal bipyramid centered on samarium are occupied by the centroids of two coordinated phenyl substituents [Sm(1)−centroid(1) = 2.919(9) Å, Sm(1)−centroid(2) = 3.277(9) Å, centroid(1)−Sm(1)−centroid(2) = 175.2(5)°] from two different aryloxides. Different from 1, the two rings are almost parallel to each other, therefore forming a slightly bent sandwich structure.

Partial thermal ellipsoid diagrams of 2 with thermal ellipsoids drawn at the 50% probability level. Hydrogen atoms and thermal ellipsoids of selected carbon atoms are omitted for clarity. Relevant bond distances (Å) and angles (deg): Sm(1)−O(3) = 2.405(7); Sm(1)−O(1) = 2.558(6); Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.603(6); Sm(1)−O(7) = 2.623(6); Sm(1)−O(6) = 2.667(6); O(3)−C(39) = 1.236(12); C(39)−C(40) = 1.532(13); O(3)−Sm(1)−O(1) = 75.0(2); O(3)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 133.5(2); O(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 60.02(17); O(3)−Sm(1)−O(7) = 78.5(2); O(1)−Sm(1)−O(7) = 151.0(2); O(2)−Sm(1)−O(7) = 147.90(19); O(3)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 140.7(2); O(1)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 139.4(2); O(2)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 85.4(2); O(7)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 63.1(2); O(5)−Al(2)−O(4) = 102.4(4); O(5)−Al(2)−C(42) = 115.2(4); O(4)−Al(2)−C(42) = 106.6(4).

The structure of 2 has three significant features. First, the divalent state of the Sm metal center has been preserved. The complex appears as generated by the simple insertion of CO2 into the Sm−CH3−Al unit without reduction despite that CO2 is well established to be an easy target for both one and twoelectron reduction reactions. Thus the failure of 1 to engage in a redox transformation with CO2 is surprising and speaks for a very substantial decrease of the reduction potential of the Sm center with this ligand environment. Second, the presence of a third aryloxide on the acetatebridged alane residue indicates that also ligand scrambling occurred during the insertion reaction. Unfortunately, we have not been able to isolate any other species from the reaction mixture, despite numerous attempts of fractional crystallization. Finally, the πbonding mode of the two phenyl rings has been preserved in spite of the treatment with coordinating ethereal solvent.

Second, the presence of a third aryloxide on the acetatebridged alane residue indicates that also ligand scrambling occurred during the insertion reaction. Unfortunately, we have not been able to isolate any other species from the reaction mixture, despite numerous attempts of fractional crystallization. Finally, the πbonding mode of the two phenyl rings has been preserved in spite of the treatment with coordinating ethereal solvent.

elements.content: Despite the presence of the paramagnetic Sm(II) metal center, the 1H NMR spectrum of 2 displays recognizable spectral features. A complex series of resonances is present in the aromatic region, which may be tentatively explained with the presence of two nonequivalent bis(phenylphenol) ligands in the ratio 1:2. Three resonances with relative intensities of 10:1:2 protons were attributed to the remote aluminumphenoxide moiety. The resonance at 7.50 integrates for 10 protons and could be assigned to the two phenyl substituents attached to the central phenoxide ring. The other two resonances are generated by the meta and paraprotons of the central ring. This assumption is also confirmed by the multiplicity of these resonances with the doublet at 7.15 and the triplet at 7.36 integrating for two and one proton, respectively. The two other phenoxide ligands are coordinated directly to the Sm(II) metal center and, as a result, reveal a more complicated pattern. Similar to the first aryloxide moiety though, the meta and paraprotons of the central phenoxide ring show one triplet at 7.45 ppm coupled to a doublet at 6.96 and integrating for two and four protons, respectively. The orthophenyl groups are magnetically nonequivalent as a possible result of the strong πinteraction of two phenyl rings with the Sm metal center. The coordinated phenyl substituents exhibit two slightly broadened signals at 7.74 and 7.75 ppm with an intensity of three protons, each tentatively assigned to ortho and paraprotons. The two metaprotons on each of the two rings provide resonances at 7.04 and 6.94 ppm with the integration of two protons each. The other two resonances at 6.42 and 6.18 ppm integrated for six and four protons and are assigned to two noninteracting rings of the ligands. Three protons of the bridging acetate unit are responsible for the appearance of a broad signal at 3.48 ppm with the expected intensity. All the remaining resonances could be assigned to the methyl groups bonded to two different Al atoms. A strong singlet at −0.22 ppm integrated for six protons and represents two methyl groups of the AlMe2 moiety separated from samarium by the acetate. The two remaining methyl groups appear to be magnetically different, providing two resonances at 2.05 and 2.08 ppm with relative intensities of three protons each and are assigned to the second Me2Al unit chelated by the two bridging aryloxides.

elements.content: The spectral features suggest that the partial πinteraction of the Sm metal center with the phenyl rings is retained in solution. Altogether, these characteristics speak for the stability of this complex. It is conceivable that this seemingly strong interaction prevents the lowvalent metal center from reducing a substrate such as CO2. It may also explain the lack of reactivity with ethylene.

elements.content: With the deliberate purpose of preventing or minimizing ligand scrambling reactions the bidentate 6,6′methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenol) was used for similar reactions. The presence of the bulky tBu groups in the proximity of the donor oxygen atom was expected to inhibit πbonding to some extent, thus introducing some lability in the complexes. The same reactions leading to 1 and under identical reaction conditions afforded in this case also vigorous gas evolution and color change upon mixing. A dark red crystalline solid was obtained directly from the mother liquor, and the formulation of the new species as (Sm{μη6′ [6,6′methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenoxy)][AlMe2]}{μMe}2{AlMe})(μMe) (3) was revealed by an Xray crystal structure (Scheme ).

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch3" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>3</label>
<graphic id="gr5" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="om-2009-00172n_0005.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The structure of complex 3 consists of a divalent Sm center coordinated to one bisaryloxide ligand and located in the center of a slightly distorted trigonal bipyramid (Figure ).

One axial position is occupied by one of the two oxygen atoms of the phenoxide ligand [Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.520(3) Å]. The second oxygen atom of the phenoxide is instead bonded to one aluminum atom. Both phenoxide donor atoms chelate one Me2Al residue. The second axial position around samarium contains a methyl group [Sm(1)−C(27) = 2.898(5) Å, C(27)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 160.84(14)°], which in turn is bridging an AlMe3 moiety [Al(2)−C(27) = 2.028(5) Å]. The unit is also using a second methyl group to bridge the Sm metal center [Al(2)−C(26) = 2.044(5) Å] by occupying one equatorial position [Sm(1)−C(26) = 2.776(5) Å, O(2)−Sm(2)−C(26) = 89.15(14)°]. In turn, a methyl group of another unit is placed in the second equatorial position of the Sm metal center [Sm(1)−C(29)A = 2.930(5) Å, O(2)−Sm(2)−C(29a) = 104.20(14)°, C(26)−Sm(2)−C(29a) = 128.77(14)°]. The last position of the equatorial plane is occupied by the centroid of the πbonded phenyl ring of the ligand [Sm(1)−centroid(1) = 2.673(5) Å, centroid(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 91.20(14)°, centroid(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 114.06(14)°].

elements.content: In line with the behavior of 1, complex 3 also appears to be unreactive toward ethylene with or without the presence of additional activators. We find this behavior even more puzzling since it is conceivable that the simple dissolution process would result in cleavage of the polymeric structure with consequent liberation of coordination sites around the Sm metal center. Unfortunately, the NMR spectra were uninformative in this case, consisting of a series of sharp resonances overlapping with several broad signals, which prevented an unequivocal interpretation. In order to evaluate the possibility of insertion versus oxidation of the samarium center, compound 3 was reacted with several cumulenes. All reaction mixtures were characterized by the formation of very dark colors, indicating that the original oxidation state of Sm(II) was again being preserved. Crystallization attempts did not produce suitable crystals in any case, with the only exception of the reaction with tertbutylisocyanate (Scheme ) and with which it was possible to obtain a highly crystalline product 4 in good yield.

elements.content: The structure of 4 shows a monomeric complex consisting of a Sm center surrounded by two diphenoxide ligands and two acetamidates (Figure ). Two AlMe residues are also part of the structure. The Sm center is located in the center of a very distorted octahedron defined by two oxygens, one from each of the two aryloxides, and the four donor atoms of the two acetamidate ligands [Sm(1)−N(1) = 2.702(4) Å, Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.562(3) Å, Sm(1)−O(3) = 2.538(3) Å, O(2)−Sm(1)−O(3) = 60.39(10)°, O(3)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 49.40(12)°]. One of the four equatorial positions is occupied by the oxygen atom of one aryloxide [Sm(1)−O(6) = 2.559(3) Å, O(2)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 127.50(11)°, N(1)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 116.49(12)°]. Two axial positions contain one oxygen of a second aryloxyde [Sm(1)−O(4) = 2.581(3) Å, O(4)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 124.73(10)°, O(4)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 111.49(12)°] and one nitrogen [Sm(1)−N(2) = 2.651(4) Å, N(2)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 92.17(13)°, N(2)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 105.26(12)°]. Each of the two tetrahedral AlMe units is chelated by the two oxygen atoms of one bisaryloxide ligand [Al(1)−O(1) = 1.707(3) Å, Al(1)−O(2) = 1.799(3) Å, O(1)−Al(1)−O(2) = 113.41(16)°]. The third position contains one oxygen atom of the acetamide ligand [Al(1)−O(3) = 1.787(4) Å, O(1)−Al(1)−O(3) = 111.10(19)°, O(2)−Al(1)−O(3) = 91.35(16)°], which in turn bridges the Sm metal center [Al(1)−O(3)−Sm(1) = 104.71(15)°].

Relevant bond distances (Å) and angles (deg): Sm(1)−O(3) = 2.538(3); Sm(1)−O(6) = 2.559(3); Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.562(3); Sm(1)−O(4) = 2.581(3); Sm(1)−N(2) = 2.651(4); Sm(1)−N(1) = 2.702(4); N(1)−C(26) = 1.256(6); N(2)−C(56) = 1.277(6); O(3)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 60.39(10); O(6)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 127.50(11); O(6)−Sm(1)−O(4) = 60.31(10); O(3)−Sm(1)−N(2) = 113.56(12); O(2)−Sm(1)−N(2) = 105.26(12); O(4)−Sm(1)−N(2) = 109.50(11); O(3)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 49.40(12); O(6)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 116.49(12); O(2)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 108.62(11); O(4)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 111.49(12); N(2)−Sm(1)−N(1) = 92.17(13); C(26)−N(1)−Sm(1) = 95.2(3); C(56)−N(2)−Sm(1) = 95.9(3); Al(1)−O(2)−Sm(1) = 103.41(14); C(26)−O(3)−Sm(1) = 100.4(3); Al(1)−O(3)−Sm(1) = 104.71(15).

The formation of 4 indicated that complex 3 behaved in a manner similar to the reaction of 1 with CO2. First the divalent oxidation state was preserved, and neither reductive coupling, nor deoxygenation was observed. Second, the formulation of 3 clearly implies ligand redistribution given that one additional bisaryloxide has been acquired by Sm during the transformation. Two ancillary Al atoms remained as part of the structure forming a bridge between the bisaryloxide moiety and the newly formed amido residue. Overall, this process could be regarded as a simple insertion of a cumulene into a Sm−C−Al array. Such a process could proceed through two different pathways. The first possibility requires a cleavage of Al−C bond with formation of a terminal SmMe residue, followed by insertion of isocyanate and recoordination of the transformed fragment to the Al metal center. A second viable option would be assuming the formation of terminal AlMe moiety accompanied by cleavage of the Me−Sm contact. In this event, the insertion would proceed at the Al center with formation of a much expected Alamidate fragment. Subsequent recoordination to the Sm metal center would not further affect the oxidation state of Sm(II).

elements.content: In order to evaluate the stability of Sm(II) toward reoxidation, a slightly stronger oxidizing agent such as azobenzene was employed. Addition of this reagent to the solution of 3 resulted in instant discoloration with formation of a new trivalent species, formulated as Sm{μ[6,6′methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenol)]2μAlMe2}{THF}2 (5) (Scheme ).

elements.content: The structure of 5 features a samarium center in a distorted octahedral environment (Figure ). The equatorial plane is defined by the four oxygen atoms of two bisaryloxide ligands [Sm(1)−O(1) = 2.155(2) Å, Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.450(2) Å, Sm(1)−O(3) = 2.154(2) Å, Sm(1)−O(4) = 2.457(2) Å, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 104.99(9)°, O(3)−Sm(1)−O(4) = 104.91(9)°, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(3) = 111.39(9)°]. Two of the four oxygen donor atoms, one per each ligand, are bridged to a dimethylaluminum cation [Sm(1)−O(2)−Al(1) = 105.20(11)°, Sm(1)−O(4)−Al(1) = 104.84(11)°, Al(1)−O(2) = 1.836(3) Å, Al(1)−O(4) = 1.839(3) Å, O(2)−Al(1)−O(4) = 87.51(12)°]. The two axial positions around samarium are occupied by two molecules of THF [Sm(1)−O(5) = 2.480(3) Å, Sm(1)−O(6) = 2.488(3) Å, O(5)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 148.50(9)°, O(3)−Sm(1)−O(5) = 81.11(9)°, O(2)−Sm(1)−O(6) = 79.10(9)°].

elements.content: In complex 5, one dimethylaluminum unit remains coordinated to the Sm ligand core through coordination to the oxygen atoms of two ligand moieties. Unfortunately, the crystallization required the use of THF, and therefore the crystal structure does not necessarily reflect the product of the reaction. In addition, the fate of azobenzene, which has undergone reduction, as well as that of several Al(Me) x units, remains unaccounted for. It is also obvious, from the final product formulation, that ligand migration took place during the transformation, the fate of the second Sm atom which has lost the ligand system also remaining unclear.

It is also obvious, from the final product formulation, that ligand migration took place during the transformation, the fate of the second Sm atom which has lost the ligand system also remaining unclear.

elements.content: The 1H NMR solution data for 5 were consistent with the solid state structure. The largest resonance at 1.36 ppm integrated for 36 protons and could be unmistakably assigned to the tertbutyl substituents on the phenyl rings of the ligands. Due to the retention of the AlMe2 unit, both ligands have two rings in a magnetically nonequivalent environment, as indicated by the slight difference of the aromatic signal locations. Two slightly broadened resonances at 6.94 and 6.79 ppm (4H each) are assigned to the ArH protons. The same nonequivalency also causes the splitting of the ArCH3 resonances, resulting in the appearance of two separate singlets at 2.16 and 2.03 ppm (6H each). The most unusual feature consists of the substantial anisotropy of the two protons of the bridging −CH2− unit. These two hydrogen atoms display considerably different chemical shifts (3.25 and 4.02 ppm). Finally, the two methyl groups of the AlMe2 unit produce two slightly separated sharp signals at −0.31 and −0.68 ppm with the expected intensity.

elements.content: As expected, complex 5 did not display catalytic activity as a singlecomponent catalyst. Only negligible activity was observed under usual Ziegler−Natta catalytic condition, when several alkyl aluminum reagents were employed as activators. On the other hand, the presence of molecules of THF in the metal coordination sphere quite possibly is responsible for the quenching of the reactivity.

elements.content: With all this information in hand, the preparation of a heterometallic, trivalent, samarium/aluminate bisaryloxide complex has been attempted in a noncoordinating environment. The choice of the trivalent state was advised by the seemingly systematic failure of these divalent derivatives to insert ethylene into the Sm−C bond. This failure is in sharp contrast with the behavior of the cyclopentadienyl samarium derivatives, which act as a polymerization catalyst as both divalent and trivalent species, and speaks for a substantial decrease of the reducing power of the divalent center in the presence of oxygendonorbased ligands. In addition, the aryloxides also are versatile ligands to support ethylene polymerization catalysts with a number of early metals. For this reason, we have reacted Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 with 2,2′methylenebis(6tertbutyl4methylphenol) in the presence of AlMe3 following the same procedure used for 1. The new trivalent peralkylated complex 6 was thus conveniently prepared in a onepot synthesis. Recrystallization from hot toluene afforded 6 in reasonable yield of wellformed, extremely airsensitive crystals (Scheme ).

<label>5</label>

Complex 6 is a symmetrygenerated dimer (Figure ) formed by two identical (bisaryloxide)−Sm(AlMe4) units and with a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry around each Sm center. The equatorial plane of the bipyramid is defined by two oxygen donor atoms of the same bisaryloxide ligand system [Sm(1)−O(1) = 2.372(2) Å, Sm(1)−O(2) = 2.095(2) Å, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(2) = 117.12(9)°]. The third position is occupied by one of the bridging methyl groups [Sm(1)−C(24) = 2.613(3) Å, C(24)−Sm(1)−O(1) = 140.66(10)°] of the AlMe4 moiety. One of the two axial positions is occupied by the second bridging methyl group [Sm(1)−C(25) = 2.632(3) Å, C(25)−Sm(1)−O(1) = 106.80(10)°, C(24)−Sm(1)−C(25) = 79.91(10)°] of the same AlMe4 unit. The second axial position around samarium is occupied by the oxygen donor atom of the bisaryloxide ligand of the second identical monomeric unit [Sm(1)−O(1a) = 2.291(2) Å, O(1a)−Sm(1)−C(25) = 153.95(9)°, O(1a)−Sm(1)−C(24) = 87.02(10)°, O(1a)−Sm(1)−O(1) = 70.14(8)°]. The two symmetryrelated oxygen atoms are responsible for the assembly of the dimer [Sm(1)−O(1)−Sm(1a) = 109.86(8)°] by forming a planar (Sm−O)2 core.

The second axial position around samarium is occupied by the oxygen donor atom of the bisaryloxide ligand of the second identical monomeric unit [Sm(1)-O(1a) = 2.291(2) Å, O(1a)-Sm(1)-C(25) = 153.95(9)°, O(1a)-Sm(1)-C(24) = 87.02(10)°, O(1a)-Sm(1)-O(1) = 70.14(8)°]. The two symmetryrelated oxygen atoms are responsible for the assembly of the dimer [Sm(1)-O(1)-Sm(1a) = 109.86(8)°] by forming a planar (Sm-O)2 core.

elements.content: Complex 6 has considerably low solubility in noncoordinating solvents at room temperature and only limited thermal stability, with some darkening of the color appearing at 110 °C. Although no tractable material was obtained from extended thermolysis in this case, it is not unreasonable to expect that the thermolysis leads to Sm(II) species. The 1H NMR spectrum of 6 was recorded at moderate temperature (40 °C) to maximize solubility. The two strongest resonances at 1.06 and 0.44 ppm accounting for nine protons each are attributed to two magnetically nonequivalent tertbutyl groups. The two methyl substituents on the phenyl rings also exhibit different chemical shifts as two singlets at 2.71 and 2.28 ppm with the expected intensity. Similarly to complex 5, two protons of the methylene bridge between two phenyl rings appear as two separate doublets (J = 3.67 Hz) at 3.61 ppm (1 proton) and 4.22 ppm (1 proton). The aromatic region contains only two resonances with intensities of two protons each at 7.15 and 7.27 ppm. Finally, the methyl groups of the aluminate unit appear as two broadened singlets at −3.96 and −1.88 ppm.

elements.content: Compound 6 polymerizes ethylene at room temperature and atmospheric pressure as a singlecomponent catalyst. The catalytic activity sharply increased (450 kg·mol−1·h−1) at 70 °C and under ethylene pressure (600 psi). In all the runs, the GPC of the samples of PE produced by this singlecomponent catalyst revealed the polymer to be broadly dispersed UHMWPE (M w = 3 342 906, PD = 21.8).

In all the runs, the GPC of the samples of PE produced by this singlecomponent catalyst revealed the polymer to be broadly dispersed UHMWPE (M w = 3342906, PD = 21.8).

elements.content: The singlecomponent catalytic activity of 6 observed under mild polymerization conditions suggests the importance of a prebuilt Sm−C−Al function in combination with steric accessibility to the Sm(III) metal center for the appearance of catalytic performance. We were in fact questioning whether a more secluded samarium center with the same functions and ligand system may or not display catalytic activity. For this purpose we have connected the samarium center of complex 6 with a second equivalent of bisphenol ligand. The reaction proceeded with intense gas evolution, and a new complex 7 was isolated with excellent yield (Scheme ).

Complex 7 consists of a Sm center surrounded by two bisaryloxide ligands, one of each in turn bridging a Me2Al residue (Figure ). The coordination geometry around samarium is an interesting pianostool type of geometry with the apical position defined by the centroid of one aromatic ring of one of the two aryloxides [Sm(1)−centroid = 2.607(5) Å, O(1)−Sm(1)−centroid = 90.30(15)°]. The basal plane is defined by three oxygen donor atoms, two from the same ligand [Sm(1)−O(3) = 2.124(4) Å, Sm(1)−O(4) = 2.092(4) Å, O(3)−Sm(1)−O(4) = 99.03(14)°, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(3) = 117.28(12)°, O(1)−Sm(1)−O(4) = 134.25(15)°] and one only from the second ligand [Sm(1)−O(1) = 2.379(3) Å]. In turn the second oxygen atom of this second ligand bonds to the tetrahedral Al residue [Al(1)−O(1)−Sm(1) = 101.66(15)°]. It should be noticed that samarium displays a short contact with one of the carbon atoms of a second phenyl ring [Sm(1)−C(1) = 3.064(5) Å].

elements.content: The structure of 7 shows the reappearance of the η6bonding of one of the phenyl rings, similar to those occurring in 3 and 1. This feature indicates to us that it is unlikely that this species is a singlecomponent catalyst given that the lability necessary to provide a vacant coordination site may be absent in this system. Accordingly, complex 7 was not a singlecomponent catalyst for ethylene polymerization even under considerable forcing of the reaction conditions.

elements.content: Peralkylated heterometallic Al/Sm complexes when isolated or generated in situ can be used as starting materials for protontransfer ligandexchange reactions. In this work we have investigated in detail these transformations with two mono and bidentate aryloxides. The isolated complexes display a common tendency toward πbonding to the Sm metal center as well as a surprising inertness of the divalent state. Reactions with cumulene led to the formation of insertion products with no evidence for the occurrence of reductive couplings. A Sm(III) compound was obtained only with the chelating bisaryloxide ligand. This species displayed substantial catalytic activity for ethylene polymerization without the need for additional activation. This compound appears to be a noncyclopentadienyl singlecomponent ethylene polymerization catalyst. The reappearance in the ligand scaffold of a πinteraction with samarium, as when a second ligand system was introduced, obliterated the catalytic activity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Peralkylated heterometallic Al/Sm complexes when isolated or generated in situ can be used as starting materials for protontransfer ligandexchange reactions. In this work we have investigated in detail these transformations with two mono and bidentate aryloxides. The isolated complexes display a common tendency toward πbonding to the Sm metal center as well as a surprising inertness of the divalent state. Reactions with cumulene led to the formation of insertion products with no evidence for the occurrence of reductive couplings. A Sm(III) compound was obtained only with the chelating bisaryloxide ligand. This species displayed substantial catalytic activity for ethylene polymerization without the need for additional activation. This compound appears to be a noncyclopentadienyl singlecomponent ethylene polymerization catalyst. The reappearance in the ligand scaffold of a πinteraction with samarium, as when a second ligand system was introduced, obliterated the catalytic activity.

A solution of 2,6diphenylphenol (0.407 g, 1.65 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was slowly added to a suspension of Sm(AlMe4)2 (0.268 g, 0.83 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). The reaction was accompanied by a fast color change from pale yellow to deep brownred and vigorous gas evolution. After 4 h of stirring at room temperature, the volume of the reaction mixture was reduced to 4 mL in vacuo and the mother liquor was allowed to stand at room temperature for crystallization. After 48 h dark red prisms of 1 separated and were washed with cold (−35 °C) toluene (3 mL) and dried in vacuo (0.565 g, 0.72 mmol 87%). Anal. for C42H44Al2O2Sm found (calcd): C 64.11 (64.25), H 5.53 (5.65).

Method B

A solution of Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 (0.200 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was treated with solution of AlMe3 in toluene (0.97 mL, 1.94 mmol, 2.0 M). A slight color change occurred. The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for an additional 30 min. After that period a solution of 2,6diphenylphenol (0.108 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added dropwise to the reaction mixture. The immediate color darkening was accompanied by a vigorous gas evolution. The solution was brought to the boiling point and evaporated to a volume of about 3 mL. The reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature. After 12 h, dark red prisms of 1 separated (0.203 g, 0.26 mmol, 81%). Analytical data and crystallographic cell parameters were nearly identical to those of the material isolated by method A.

Preparation of Sm{[(μ2,6bis(phenylphenoxy))<sub>2</sub>AlMe<sub>2</sub>][μ(acetato)(2,6bis(phenylphenoxy))Al Me<sub>2</sub>][1,2dimethoxyethane]}{C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>14</sub>}<sub>0.25</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A dark redbrown solution of 1 (0.450 g, 0.57 mmol) in toluene (7 mL) was exposed to CO2 (1 atm). No color change was observed at room temperature, and the reaction mixture was brought to the boiling point and refluxed under CO2 atmosphere for 15 min. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, and the toluene solvent was removed in vacuo. The resulting dark red oil was redissolved in the minimum amount of DME (4 mL) under an N2 atmosphere. The DME solution was layered with hexanes (13 mL). After 48 h, dark red prisms of 2 were formed from the solution (0.283 g, 0.24 mmol, 42%). Upon drying in vacuo crystals rapidly deteriorated with formation of a red powdery material. Anal. for a dried sample of C64H64Al2O7Sm found (calcd): C 66.74 (66.87), H 5.57 (5.61). 1H NMR (500 MHz, benzened 6, 20 °C): δ 7.75(3H, ortho, paraAr′H), 7.74(3H, ortho, paraAr′H), 7.50(10H, Ar′′H), 7.45(2H, paraArH), 7.36(1H, paraArH), 7.15(2H, metaArH), 7.04(2H, metaAr′H), 6.96(4H, metaArH), 6.90(2H, metaAr′H), 6.42(6H, ortho,paraAr′H), 6.18(4H, metaAr′H), 3.48(broad, 3H, CH 3COO), 2.08(3H, AlCH 3), 2.05(3H, AlCH 3), −0.22(6H, AlCH 3).

Preparation of (Sm{μ<italic toggle="yes"></italic>η<sup>6</sup>′[6,6′methylenebis(2<italic toggle="yes">tert</italic>butyl4methylphenoxy)][AlMe<sub>2</sub>]}{μMe}<sub>2</sub>{AlMe})(μMe) (<bold>3</bold>)

A solution of bisphenol (0.161 g, 0.47 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a suspension of Sm(AlMe4)2 (0.153 g, 0.47 mmol) in the same solvent (5 mL). Vigorous gas evolution and significant color change from pale pink to deep red were observed upon mixing. The reaction mixture was brought to the boiling point, and the volume was reduced by about 2 mL. The reaction mixture was allowed to cool to room temperature, and after 24 h dark red plates of 3 were formed (0.272 g, 0.43 mmol, 91%). Anal. for C29H48Al2O2Sm found (calcd): C 54.92 (55.02), H 7.55 (7.64).

Preparation of Sm{μ[6,6′methylenebis(2<italic toggle="yes">tert</italic>butyl4methylphenol)]μ[<italic toggle="yes">N</italic> <italic toggle="yes">tert</italic>butylacetamidate]AlMe}<sub>2</sub>{C<sub>7</sub>H<sub>8</sub>}<sub>1.5</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A solution of tertbutylisocyanate (0.045 g, 0.46 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added dropwise with vigorous stirring to a solution of 3 (0.275 g, 0.43 mmol) in the same solvent (10 mL). No significant immediate color change was observed from the initial deep red, and stirring was continued for an additional 5 h. After that period of time, the volume was reduced in vacuo to about 4 mL. The solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for 3 days, after which large greenishbrown prisms of 4 separated. The crystalline mass was isolated, washed with cold toluene (−35 °C), and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.235 g, 0.18 mmol, 43%.). Anal. for C70.5H102N2Al2O6Sm found (calcd): C 66.21 (66.26), H 7.98 (8.05), N 2.15 (2.19).

Preparation of Sm{μ[6,6′methylenebis(2<italic toggle="yes">tert</italic>butyl4methylphenol)]<sub>2</sub>μ<italic toggle="yes"></italic>AlMe<sub>2</sub>}{THF}<sub>2</sub>{C<sub>6</sub> H<sub>14</sub>}<sub>0.5</sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

A solution of diazobenzene (0.059 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (4 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 3 (0.410 g, 0.65 mmol) in toluene (10 mL). An immediate color change from the initial deep red was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued for 3 h at room temperature. After that time a significant amount of colorless solid separated from the mother liquor. The mother liquor was discarded, and the colorless solid was redissolved in THF (5 mL). A very small amount of insoluble material was eliminated by centrifugation. The resulting clear solution was layered with hexane (10 mL) and left undisturbed at room temperature for three days. The colorless crystalline 5 thus separated was washed with cold hexane (−35 °C) and dried under an N2 atmosphere (0.290 g, 0.27 mmol 42%). Upon drying in vacuo, crystals rapidly deteriorated with the formation of a white powdery material. Anal. for a dried sample of C56H82AlO6Sm found (calcd): C 65.31 (65.39), H 7.97 (8.04). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THFd 8, 20 °C): δ 6.94(4H, ArH), 6.79(4H, ArH), 4.02(2H, −CH 2−), 3.53(8H, THF), 3.25(2H, −CH 2−), 2.16(6H, ArCH 3), 2.03(6 H, ArCH 3), 1.73(8H, THF), 1.36(36H, C(CH 3)3), −0.31(3H, AlCH 3), −0.68(3H, AlCH 3).

Preparation {Smμ[6,6′methylenebis(2<italic toggle="yes">tert</italic>butyl4methylphenol)][μMe<sub>2</sub>AlMe<sub>2</sub>]}<sub>2</sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

A solution of Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 (0.200 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (10 mL) was treated with a solution of AlMe3 in toluene (0.97 mL, 2.0 M, 1.94 mmol) and stirred for 2 h at room temperature. A solution of bisphenol (0.108 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (7 mL) was then added dropwise to the reaction mixture. A vigorous gas evolution and significant color change from pale yellow to bright orange were observed upon mixing, and the reaction mixture was stirred for an additional 3 h. The solution was concentrated to 4 mL and allowed to cool. Upon cooling, a large amount of bright orange, highly crystalline 6 separated, which was washed with cold toluene (−35 °C) and dried in vacuo (0.156 g, 0.27 mmol, 84%). Anal. for C54H84Al2O4Sm2 found (calcd): C 56.22 (56.30), H 7.07 (7.35). 1H NMR (500 MHz, toluened 8, 40 °C): δ 7.27(2H, ArH), 7.15(2H, ArH), 4.22(1H, −CH 2−), 3.61(1H, −CH 2−), 2.71(3H, ArCH 3), 2.28(3H, ArCH 3), 1.06(9H, −C(CH 3)3), 0.44(9H, −C(CH 3)3), −1.88(6H, AlCH 3), −3.96(6H, AlCH 3).

Preparation of Sm{μ[6,6′methylenebis(2<italic toggle="yes">tert</italic>butyl4methylphenoxy)]}<sub>2</sub>μAlMe<sub>2</sub> (<bold>7</bold>)

A solution of bisphenol (0.111 g, 0.33 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of bright orange 6 (0.188 g, 0.33 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). Intense gas evolution and discoloration to pale yellow was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued for an additional 3 h. The volume of the mixture was reduced to about 4 mL by evaporation, and the resulting solution was brought to the boiling point and allowed to cool undisturbed to room temperature. After 6 h, yellow prisms of 7 were formed, which were separated from the mother liquor and dried under an N2 atmosphere (0.248 g, 0.28 mmol, 85%). Anal. for C48H66AlO4Sm found (calcd): C 65.03 (65.19), H 7.41 (7.52). 1H NMR (500 MHz, benzened 6, 20 °C): δ 10.58(2H, ArH), 9.86(2H, ArH), 8.13(2H, ArH), 8.12(2H, ArH), 4.92(1H, −CH 2−), 4.09(1H, −CH 2−), 3.83(1H, −CH 2−), 3.58(3H, ArCH 3), 3.41(1H, −CH 2−), 2.87(3H, ArCH 3), 2.68(3H, ArCH 3), 2.38 (3H, ArCH 3), 1.61(18H, −C(CH 3)3), 1.57(18H, −C(CH 3)3), −4.02(3H, AlCH 3), −4.15(3H, AlCH 3).

Anal. for C29H48Al2O2Sm found (calcd): C 54.92 (55.02), H 7.55 (7.64).

Preparation of Sm{μ[6,6'methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenol)]μ[N tertbutylacetamidate]AlMe}2{C7H8}1.5 (4)

A solution of tertbutylisocyanate (0.045 g, 0.46 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added dropwise with vigorous stirring to a solution of 3 (0.275 g, 0.43 mmol) in the same solvent (10 mL). No significant immediate color change was observed from the initial deep red, and stirring was continued for an additional 5 h. After that period of time, the volume was reduced in vacuo to about 4 mL. The solution was allowed to stand at room temperature for 3 days, after which large greenishbrown prisms of 4 separated. The crystalline mass was isolated, washed with cold toluene (-35 °C), and dried under N2 atmosphere (0.235 g, 0.18 mmol, 43%.). Anal. for C70.5H102N2Al2O6Sm found (calcd): C 66.21 (66.26), H 7.98 (8.05), N 2.15 (2.19).

Preparation of Sm{μ[6,6'methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenol)]2μAlMe2}{THF}2{C6 H14}0.5 (5)

A solution of diazobenzene (0.059 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (4 mL) was added dropwise to a solution of 3 (0.410 g, 0.65 mmol) in toluene (10 mL). An immediate color change from the initial deep red was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued for 3 h at room temperature. After that time a significant amount of colorless solid separated from the mother liquor. The mother liquor was discarded, and the colorless solid was redissolved in THF (5 mL). A very small amount of insoluble material was eliminated by centrifugation. The resulting clear solution was layered with hexane (10 mL) and left undisturbed at room temperature for three days. The colorless crystalline 5 thus separated was washed with cold hexane (-35 °C) and dried under an N2 atmosphere (0.290 g, 0.27 mmol 42%). Upon drying in vacuo, crystals rapidly deteriorated with the formation of a white powdery material. Anal. for a dried sample of C56H82AlO6Sm found (calcd): C 65.31 (65.39), H 7.97 (8.04). 1H NMR (500 MHz, THFd 8, 20 °C): δ 6.94(4H, ArH), 6.79(4H, ArH), 4.02(2H, -CH 2-), 3.53(8H, THF), 3.25(2H, -CH 2-), 2.16(6H, ArCH 3), 2.03(6 H, ArCH 3), 1.73(8H, THF), 1.36(36H, C(CH 3)3), -0.31(3H, AlCH 3), -0.68(3H, AlCH 3).

Preparation {Smμ[6,6'methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenol)][μMe2AlMe2]}2 (6)

A solution of Sm[N(SiMe3)2]3 (0.200 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (10 mL) was treated with a solution of AlMe3 in toluene (0.97 mL, 2.0 M, 1.94 mmol) and stirred for 2 h at room temperature. A solution of bisphenol (0.108 g, 0.32 mmol) in toluene (7 mL) was then added dropwise to the reaction mixture. A vigorous gas evolution and significant color change from pale yellow to bright orange were observed upon mixing, and the reaction mixture was stirred for an additional 3 h. The solution was concentrated to 4 mL and allowed to cool. Upon cooling, a large amount of bright orange, highly crystalline 6 separated, which was washed with cold toluene (-35 °C) and dried in vacuo (0.156 g, 0.27 mmol, 84%). Anal. for C54H84Al2O4Sm2 found (calcd): C 56.22 (56.30), H 7.07 (7.35). 1H NMR (500 MHz, toluened 8, 40 °C): δ 7.27(2H, ArH), 7.15(2H, ArH), 4.22(1H, -CH 2-), 3.61(1H, -CH 2-), 2.71(3H, ArCH 3), 2.28(3H, ArCH 3), 1.06(9H, -C(CH 3)3), 0.44(9H, -C(CH 3)3), -1.88(6H, AlCH 3), -3.96(6H, AlCH 3).

Preparation of Sm{μ[6,6'methylenebis(2tertbutyl4methylphenoxy)]}2μAlMe2 (7)

A solution of bisphenol (0.111 g, 0.33 mmol) in toluene (5 mL) was added to a solution of bright orange 6 (0.188 g, 0.33 mmol) in toluene (5 mL). Intense gas evolution and discoloration to pale yellow was observed upon mixing, and stirring was continued for an additional 3 h. The volume of the mixture was reduced to about 4 mL by evaporation, and the resulting solution was brought to the boiling point and allowed to cool undisturbed to room temperature. After 6 h, yellow prisms of 7 were formed, which were separated from the mother liquor and dried under an N2 atmosphere (0.248 g, 0.28 mmol, 85%). Anal. for C48H66AlO4Sm found (calcd): C 65.03 (65.19), H 7.41 (7.52). 1H NMR (500 MHz, benzened 6, 20 °C): δ 10.58(2H, ArH), 9.86(2H, ArH), 8.13(2H, ArH), 8.12(2H, ArH), 4.92(1H, -CH 2-), 4.09(1H, -CH 2-), 3.83(1H, -CH 2-), 3.58(3H, ArCH 3), 3.41(1H, -CH 2-), 2.87(3H, ArCH 3), 2.68(3H, ArCH 3), 2.38 (3H, ArCH 3), 1.61(18H, -C(CH 3)3), 1.57(18H, -C(CH 3)3), -4.02(3H, AlCH 3), -4.15(3H, AlCH 3).

cln_elements.content: Compound 6 polymerizes ethylene at room temperature and atmospheric pressure as a singlecomponent catalyst. The catalytic activity sharply increased (450 kg·mol−1·h−1) at 70 °C and under ethylene pressure (600 psi). In all the runs, the GPC of the samples of PE produced by this singlecomponent catalyst revealed the polymer to be broadly dispersed UHMWPE (M w = 3 342 906, PD = 21.8).

metadata.title: Aluminate Samarium(II) and Samarium(III) Aryloxides. Isolation of a Single-Component Ethylene Polymerization Catalyst
